title: How to Edit the Windows Registry

steps.title: Make a backup of the Windows Registry.
steps.content: Make a backup of the Windows Registry. Do this before you edit it so you can revert to the pre-edited version if necessary.

steps.title: Press ⊞ Win+r.
steps.content: Press ⊞ Win + r . The Run window opens.

steps.title: Type "regedit" without the quotes and press ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Type "regedit" without the quotes and press ↵ Enter . If prompted by User Account Control, click Yes to open the Registry Editor.

steps.title: Right-click the Computer icon in the left pane.
steps.content: Right-click the Computer icon in the left pane.

steps.title: Choose a location and type a name for the backup.
steps.content: Choose a location and type a name for the backup.

steps.title: Edit the Registry.
steps.content: Edit the Registry. The Registry contains two basic elements: keys and values. If you know the key you want to edit, press Control + f to open the Find dialog box. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Type the key name and click Find Next.
steps.content: Type the key name and click Find Next .

steps.title: Edit the key's value data.
steps.content: Edit the key's value data. When you find the key, double-click it to edit the value data.

steps.title: Click OK to save your edits.
steps.content: Click OK to save your edits. Some edits may require a Windows restart to take effect.

steps.title: If necessary, you can restore your Registry backup.
steps.content: If necessary, you can restore your Registry backup. Keep track of your edits so you can return them to their original value if desired. If you make multiple unsatisfactory edits, you may want to restore your entire Registry backup rather than correct each edit.

steps.title: In the File menu click Import.
steps.content: In the File menu click Import.

steps.title: Locate the backup file you saved and click Open.
steps.content: Locate the backup file you saved and click Open.
